questions.question: A 65-year-old male is in cardiac arrest due to refractory ventricular fibrillation after three unsuccessful defibrillation attempts. The resuscitation team decides to use double external defibrillation. What is the correct placement for the first defibrillator, and how should the second be positioned?

options.A: A) Left sternal border and left axilla; close to the first.
options.B: B) Right sternal border and cardiac apex; antero-posterior position.
options.C: C) Both pads on the same side; on the abdomen for the second.
options.D: D) Anteriorly on the chest; also anterior for the second with no specific placement.

questions.explanation: do not touch. The second can be positioned antero-posteriorly or close to the first. Double sequential defibrillation Double external defibrillation (DED) involves using two defibrillators on a single patient with refractory ventricular fibrillation (RVF) during cardiac arrest. As of November 2020, the American Heart Association does not recommend DED for refractory shockable rhythms due to insufficient evidence of its usefulness. DED is considered after three failed attempts with a single defibrillator. DEFIBRILLATOR 1: Medial/Lateral Placement: First pad placed near the right sternal border pad. Second pad placed near the cardiac apex pad. Ensure pads do not touch to avoid damage to the defibrillator. DEFIBRILLATOR 2: Two methods of placing the 2nd defibrillator Either set up the second set close to the first set of defibrillators. Or Antero-posterior placement. questions.question: A 35-year-old male mountaineer plans a rapid ascent to an altitude of 4500 meters for a climbing expedition. He has a history of experiencing symptoms like fatigue, non-productive cough, and difficulty breathing during previous high-altitude trips. Based on the scenario, which of the following strategies should the mountaineer implement to effectively prevent symptoms, and what is the main treatment he should consider if symptoms develop? acetazolamide. if symptoms occur. arise.

options.A: Maintain an average altitude gain exceeding 300 m per day, and begin immediate treatment with
options.B: Ascend rapidly without acclimatization, and use supplemental oxygen if symptoms develop.
options.C: Ascend slowly with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day, and prioritize descent of 1000 meters
options.D: Use alcohol to relax during the ascent, and rely solely on portable hyperbaric chambers if symptoms

questions.explanation: descent of 1000 meters if symptoms occur. previous symptoms, which include fatigue, cough, and dyspnea. Effective prevention involves a slow ascent with a maximum altitude gain of 300 m per day and the primary treatment for symptoms is immediate descent of 1000 meters to alleviate hypoxia and reduce pulmonary edema. High altitude pulmonary edema Prevention Slow ascent is the most effective method of prevention, even for susceptible individuals. Graded ascent and adequate time for acclimatization. Low sleeping altitudes. Avoidance of alcohol and sleeping pills. Avoidance of vigorous exercise, especially during the first days at altitude. Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, can prevent HAPE in individuals with a history of the condition. The recommended dosage is 60 mg daily of a slow-release formulation, starting during ascent and continuing until the third or fourth day after arrival at the final altitude or after descending below 3000 m. Preliminary data suggest glucocorticoids may prevent HAPE when taken one day prior to ascent and continued during ascent at high altitude. Susceptible individuals should maintain an average altitude gain not exceeding 300 m per day above 2500 m. If progressive acclimatization is not possible, prophylaxis with nifedipine or tadalafil is recommended for long stays at high altitude, and dexamethasone for short stays of less than 5 days. Treatment The mainstay of treatment is to descend 1000 meters or until symptoms resolve. Minimize exertion during descent to reduce hypoxemia and worsening condition. Oxygen therapy may help alleviate symptoms if descent is delayed or difficult. Main treatment remains descent, regardless of oxygen availability. Supplemental oxygen via high-flow nasal cannula and facemask should be titrated to SpO2 greater than 90%. Portable hyperbaric chambers can be used if descent is not possible but require constant care. Hyperbaric chambers may be challenging for individuals with nausea, vomiting, claustrophobia, or altered mental status from AMS/HACE. There is a risk of symptom recurrence after exiting the hyperbaric chamber. Nifedipine can improve symptoms as an adjunct therapy by reducing pulmonary vasoconstriction. Nifedipine should not be the sole therapy if descent or oxygen is an option. Phosphodiesterase inhibitors may help decrease pulmonary artery and capillary pressure through vasodilation if nifedipine is unavailable. There is no clinically proven role for acetazolamide, β -agonists, or diuretics in the treatment of HAPE. Maintain an average altitude gain exceeding 300 m per day, and begin

questions.question: A 28-year-old male skier is found unresponsive in the snow with a core body temperature of 27°C (81°F). He exhibits severe hypothermia and requires immediate medical attention. Which of the following is NOT a treatment approach for managing his hypothermia? support.

options.A: A) Administer warm intravenous fluids at 40-42°C.
options.B: B) Utilize ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) to provide rewarming and circulatory
options.C: C) Use passive external rewarming by layering him with wet clothing.
options.D: D) Perform active internal rewarming using warm saline lavage of body cavities.

questions.explanation: defined as a drop in core body temperature below 28°C. This condition disrupts the body's ability to maintain homeostasis, leading to potential organ failure and life-threatening complications. Layering with wet clothing can exacerbate heat loss, as wet materials conduct heat away from the body more efficiently than dry materials. Effective treatment for hypothermia requires removing wet clothing and using dry insulation to help retain body heat. Treatment of Hypothermia: Initial Management: Focus on rapid rewarming, preventing heat loss, and ensuring airway, breathing, and circulation are managed. Clothing: Remove wet clothing and replace it with dry insulation immediately. Gentle Handling: Move moderate/severe hypothermic patients gently to avoid fatal arrhythmias due to cardiac irritability. Glucose: Administer oral glucose for patients with documented hypoglycemia. Rewarming Techniques: Passive External Rewarming (for mild hypothermia): Remove wet clothing and apply insulating layers. Shivering aids in heat generation, but requires glucose stores. Rate of rewarming: 0.5 to 2°C per hour. Active External Rewarming (for moderate to severe hypothermia or refractory mild cases): Use heated air units to reduce heat loss (e.g., warm air blankets). Apply heated packs to axillae, chest, and back. Water immersion (44-45°C) can be used but must be done with care due to risks of cold blood returning to circulation (increased cardiac load). Active Internal Rewarming (for severe hypothermia): Airway rewarming with humidified warm air. Warm intravenous (IV) fluids (40-42°C). (Option A ruled out) Warm saline lavage of body cavities (e.g., stomach, bladder, colon, peritoneum, pleura). (Option D ruled out) Pleural lavage: Insert two thoracostomy tubes (anterior and posterior) for warm fluid infusion and drainage. Peritoneal lavage: Insert multiple catheters, useful for trauma detection and rewarming. 4. Extracorporeal Rewarming: Hemodialysis: Most accessible, increases core temperature by 2-3°C per hour. Arteriovenous (AV) Rewarming: Warm femoral arterial blood flows to the contralateral femoral vein, raising temperature by 4.5°C per hour. Requires adequate blood pressure. Cardiopulmonary Bypass & ECMO (for cardiac arrest or hemodynamically unstable patients): (Option B ruled out) Most rapid rewarming methods (7-10°C per hour). Provides simultaneous circulatory and oxygenation support. Requires systemic anticoagulation, increasing bleeding risk. Reference: Hypothermia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 40-year-old male fisherman is rescued after being exposed to cold water for several hours. Upon examination, his core body temperature is 29°C (84°F). He shows signs of lethargy, dilated pupils, and a slow heart rate. Which of the following statements about his condition is false?

options.A: Mild hypothermia typically presents with symptoms like shivering and increased muscle tone.
options.B: In moderate hypothermia shivering generally stops as the body temperature approaches 30°C.
options.C: Severe hypothermia can lead to unresponsiveness and increased risk of cardiac dysrhythmias.
options.D: Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C.

questions.explanation: below 28°C. Correct answer: D) Osborn waves are typically absent in hypothermic patients with temperatures below 28°C. Exaplanation: This patient has hypothermia , characterized by a core body temperature of 29°C, leading to symptoms such as lethargy, dilated pupils, and bradycardia. This condition results from prolonged exposure to cold, affecting the body's ability to maintain normal temperature and function. Osborn (J) waves are often present in hypothermic patients and can indicate the severity of the condition. J waves seen in ECG Hypothermia Definition Hypothermia is defined as a drop in core body temperature below 35°C, resulting in the failure to maintain homeostasis and affecting all organ systems. Types Primary Hypothermia : Caused by environmental cold exposure, such as cold air or water. Common in cold geographic areas but can also occur in mild climates. Secondary Hypothermia : Results from conditions that impair heat production or increase heat loss (e.g., trauma, burns, drug overdoses, endocrine disorders, CNS injury, or drug effects). Clinical Features Mild Hypothermia (32-35°C / 90-95°F) (Option A) Symptoms: Hunger, nausea, fatigue, shivering, pale/dry skin, increased muscle tone, blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration. Neurologic symptoms: Cognitive decline, memory impairment, ataxia, dysarthria. Shivering may stop if energy stores are depleted (e.g., malnutrition). Cold-induced diuresis due to peripheral vasoconstriction. Moderate Hypothermia (28-32°C / 82-90°F) (Option B) Cognitive decline, lethargy, CNS depression (hyporeflexia, dilated pupils). Shivering stops at 30-32°C. Paradoxical undressing may occur. Increased risk of atrial fibrillation, hypotension, bradycardia, bradypnea. Severe Hypothermia (<28°C / <82°F) (Option C) Unresponsiveness, further decline in cerebral blood flow, hypotension, bradycardia, and cardiac output. Risk of atrial, junctional dysrhythmias. Pulmonary congestion, oliguria, and areflexia. Potential for cardiorespiratory failure and death. ECG Findings Atrial Fibrillation : Most common arrhythmia in hypothermic patients. Bradycardia : Seen in moderate to severe hypothermia, increasing the risk of ventricular arrhythmias. QT Interval Prolongation : Due to slowed impulse conduction through potassium channels. Osborn (J) Waves : Elevated J point, visible on ECG in the precordial leads, with wave height proportional to the degree of hypothermia.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male hiker ascends rapidly from sea level to an altitude of 4500 meters over 24 hours. Two days after his arrival, he begins to experience increasing fatigue, a non-productive cough, and difficulty breathing during physical activity. His oxygen saturation is 60% on examination, and he exhibits tachypnea and cyanosis. Based on the scenario, which factors do not contribute to the patient's clinical features?

options.B: Use of sleep medications during ascent
options.C: Recent heavy physical exertion prior to ascent

questions.explanation: characteristic of acute HAPE, a severe form of altitude sickness resulting from hypoxia and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. An extended acclimatization period is protective against altitude sickness. It allows the body to adjust to lower oxygen levels gradually, thereby reducing the risk of developing HAPE (High altitude pulmonary edema). High altitude pulmonary edema About HAPE is a severe, high-altitude illness, potentially fatal. It is noncardiogenic pulmonary edema caused by hypoxia. It occurs above 2500 meters, and can start as low as 2000 meters. Risk factors: low hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR), rapid ascent, male sex, sleep medications, high salt intake, cold temperatures, and heavy exertion. Pre-existing conditions (e.g., pulmonary hypertension) increase risk. Faster ascent correlates with higher incidence. Pathophysiology HAPE results from the pulmonary vasculature's response to hypoxia. Hypoxic ventilatory response (HVR) varies among individuals and has a genetic component. High altitude adaptations include changes in resting ventilation, HVR, oxygen saturation, and hemoglobin concentration. Rapid ascent to altitude causes immediate increases in minute ventilation and respiratory alkalosis. Shifts in the oxygen-dissociation curve occur, initially increasing oxygen affinity, followed by a decrease as 2,3-DPG levels rise. Blunted HVR (due to genetic factors or sedatives) leads to exaggerated hypoxemic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV). HPV increases perfusion to affected alveoli, raising capillary pressures and permeability, leading to non-uniform pulmonary edema. This edema further impedes oxygen transport and exacerbates pulmonary hypertension. Clinical features HAPE typically manifests 2 to 5 days after arriving at high altitude. Initial symptoms include non-productive cough, decreased exercise tolerance, chest pain, and exertional dyspnea. Progression can lead to dyspnea at rest, productive cough with pink frothy sputum, rales, and cyanosis. Patients may exhibit tachypnea and tachycardia. SpO2 levels are often significantly lower than expected for altitude, with values typically ranging from 40% to 70%. Low hypoxic ventilatory response (Option A) : A low HVR is a significant risk factor for developing altitude-related illnesses, including HAPE. It impairs the body's ability to respond to low oxygen levels, making it more likely for the patient to experience severe hypoxia and associated symptoms. Use of sleep medications during ascent (Option B) : Sleep medications can depress the respiratory drive, leading to a reduced HVR. This can worsen hypoxia at high altitudes, increasing the risk of HAPE and contributing to the patient's clinical features. Recent heavy physical exertion prior to ascent (Option C) : Engaging in heavy physical exertion can lead to fatigue and increased susceptibility to altitude sickness,

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman, 36 weeks pregnant, is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. Upon arrival, she is unresponsive and in cardiac arrest. CPR is initiated immediately. The team begins advanced cardiac life support for pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes?

options.A: Delay chest compressions to position the patient for cesarean section.
options.B: Place the patient in a left lateral decubitus position and perform left uterine displacement.
options.C: Administer 2 mg epinephrine IV every 5 minutes.
options.D: Delay defibrillation to avoid harm to the fetus.

questions.explanation: displacement. uterine displacement (LUD) is crucial in pregnancy to optimize maternal resuscitation efforts. Cardiac Arrest in Pregnancy Mnemonic Causes of maternal cardiac arrest A Anesthetic Complications (Aspiration, High neuraxial block, Respiratory depression) Accidents/ Trauma B Bleeding (Uterine atony, Placenta accreta, Abruption, Uterine rupture) C Cardiovascular Causes (MI, Cardiomyopathy, Valve disease, Congenital heart disease) D Drug-Related Issues (Oxytocin, Opioids, Illicit drugs, Anaphylaxis) E Embolic Causes (Amniotic fluid, Pulmonary, Venous air embolism) F Fever (Sepsis, Infection) G General Issues - H’s and T’s (causes of cardiac arrest) H Hypertension (Preeclampsia, Eclampsia, HELLP syndrome) Cardiac Arrest Management in Pregnancy Place the patient in a full left lateral decubitus position to relieve aortocaval compression. Administer 100% oxygen via face mask to treat or prevent hypoxemia. Establish intravenous access above the diaphragm to prevent obstruction by the gravid uterus. Identify and treat any precipitating factors contributing to cardiac arrest. A pregnant patient with in-hospital cardiac arrest should not be transported for cesarean delivery. Management should occur at the site of the arrest. (Option A ruled out) Immediately perform chest compressions (CPR) at a rate of at least 100 per minute, with a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), allowing full recoil. Limit interruptions to 10 seconds, except for advanced airway placement or defibrillation. Continuously perform manual left uterine displacement (LUD) if the uterus is palpated at or above the umbilicus. Use the same defibrillation protocol as in nonpregnant patients, applying biphasic shocks of 120 to 200 J, escalating if necessary. (Option D ruled out) For refractory ventricular fibrillation or tachycardia, administer amiodarone 300 mg rapid infusion, with 150 mg doses as needed. Consider administering 1 mg epinephrine IV/IO every 3 to 5 minutes during cardiac arrest; it is preferred over vasopressin. (Option C ruled out) If maternal resuscitation fails, consider a cesarean section if the gestational age is greater than 23 weeks, ideally performed within 4 minutes after maternal arrest to maximize fetal survival. Fetal Survival : The earlier the fetus is delivered following maternal arrest, the better the chances of survival, with the best outcomes if delivered within 5 minutes of CPR initiation. Supine Hypotensive syndrome Supine hypotensive syndrome occurs in late pregnancy (usually after 20 weeks) due to the gravid uterus compressing the inferior vena cava and aorta when a pregnant woman lies on her back, leading to maternal hypotension. Treatment involves repositioning the patient to alleviate compression, either by turning her onto her left side or manually displacing the uterus if spine immobilization is needed.

questions.question: A 62-year-old man was found unconscious at home and resuscitated after a cardiac arrest. He achieved Return of Spontaneous Circulation (ROSC) and was admitted to the ICU. By Day 3 (49-72 hours post-ROSC), the patient has been rewarmed, and sedation is being weaned off. Which of the following is an appropriate neuro-prognostic assessment to perform at this stage if the clinical condition allows it?

options.A: Perform a routine EEG to assess for seizure activity
options.D: Perform a neurological exam with a focus on pupillary and motor responses

questions.explanation: Day 3 post-ROSC (49-72 hours). SSEP measures the integrity of sensory pathways, particularly the brain's response to electrical stimulation of peripheral nerves. A poor SSEP result (bilateral absence of cortical responses) in a comatose patient is associated with a poor neurological outcome. Perform a routine EEG to assess for seizure activity (Option A): Routine EEG is typically done within the first 24 hours post-ROSC to assess for seizures, not on Day 3. By this stage, other prognostic tests are more appropriate. Incorrect option. Initiate Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) (Option C): TTM is started within the first 24 hours post-ROSC, not on Day 3. Perform a neurological exam with a focus on pupillary and motor responses (Option D): A detailed neuro exam is more useful after full sedation is weaned off, usually beyond 72 hours. At 49-72 hours, SSEP is a better choice. Less appropriate here.

IHCA- In-hospital cardiac arrest; OHCA- Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest Option A, C & D are incorrect orders of OHCA. Upon arrival, the medical team begins CPR and attaches a monitor/defibrillator. The rhythm check shows asystole. What is the next step in managing this child according to the Pediatric Cardiac Arrest Algorithm?
questions.explanation: treatment involves continuing CPR and administering Epinephrine as soon as possible (Step 10). Amiodarone : Begin with 300 mg IV/IO; a follow-up dose of 150 mg IV/IO may be administered if needed. An alternative dose is 5 mg/kg IV. Lidocaine : Start with 1-1.5 mg/kg IV. If ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) persists, administer 0.5-0.75 mg/kg IV every 5-10 minutes, up to a maximum of 3 mg/kg. cardiac arrest algorithm" data-author="" data-hash="11254" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/6VUo2cprLO85a9bjRIFq1745563907.png" /> Defibrillation (shock) (Option A) is not indicated for asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA), which are non-shockable rhythms. questions.question: Which of the following statements about massive transfusion management are correct? A) PRBC should be administered first to address hypoxia and acidosis. B) Blood components should be transfused in a 1:1:1 ratio of PRBC: FFP: PRP, beginning with PRBC. C) Blood products should be warmed during transfusion to prevent hypothermia-induced coagulopathy. D) Platelets should be administered first to prevent coagulopathy. E) Components are stored at different temperatures: PRBC at 4°C, FFP at -30°C (thawed before use), and platelets at room temperature (20-24°C).

options.B: A, B, C, and E only

questions.explanation: In the massive transfusion protocol, PRBC must be administered first because, in a bleeding patient, blood loss causes hypoxia and acidosis . PRBC carries oxygen and helps neutralize the acidosis component. This is important because acidosis impairs the ability of blood to clot, which could worsen coagulopathy. Also, ABC Score ≥ 2 predicts massive transfusion needs (75% accuracy). Platelets should not be given first as their function would be impaired by acidosis. The ratio of PRBC:FFP: PRP should be maintained at 1:1:1, but the sequence must start with PRBC. Warming of blood products is essential during rapid transfusion to prevent hypothermia, which is a significant risk in trauma patients receiving large volumes of cold blood products. Hypothermia can lead to coagulopathy , worsening the bleeding. Administering all components simultaneously without warming could result in hypothermia-induced coagulopathy and other associated complications. Massive Transfusion Definition: Blood loss of 150 ml/min within 20 minutes Requires replacement equal to blood loss Components and Ratios: PRBC:FFP: PRP = 1:1:1 1 unit SDP = 6 units PRP Components stored at different temperatures: PRBC: Red cooler (4°C) FFP: -30°C (thawed before use) Platelets: Room temperature (20-24°C) Sequence : PRBC first: Addresses hypoxia and acidosis Acidosis impairs clotting Platelets are given later as they're affected by acidosis Setup Requirements: Pressurized rapid transfuser- Ensures infusion rate matches blood loss In-line warmers- Prevents hypothermia-induced coagulopathy Reference: II www.uptodate.com/contents/massive-blood-transfusion www.hematology.org/education/clinicians/gu idelines-and-quality-care/clinical-practice-guidelines/guidelines-for-massive-transfusion

questions.question: A 35-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after being bitten by a snake on his left ankle. He presents with severe swelling of the left leg, gingival bleeding, and incoagulable blood on the 20-minute whole blood clotting time test. You decide to administer polyvalent antivenom serum (ASV). Twenty minutes after starting the ASV infusion, the patient develops urticaria, cough, and abdominal pain. His blood pressure drops to 85/50 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.B: Continue ASV infusion and administer corticosteroids
options.C: Stop ASV infusion temporarily and treat with epinephrine

questions.explanation: within 10-180 minutes of starting treatment. The symptoms presented (urticaria, cough, abdominal pain, and hypotension) are typical of this reaction. The correct management for an early ASV reaction is as follows: Stop the ASV infusion immediately. Administer epinephrine (adrenaline) intramuscularly or subcutaneously. Give antihistamines and corticosteroids. Treat shock if present (IV fluids, oxygen). Once symptoms have subsided, resume ASV administration at a slower rate. ASV Complications and Management Complication Timing Symptoms Management Early (Anaphylactic) Reaction 10-180 minutes after starting ASV - Itching, urticaria - Nausea, vomiting - Cough, abdominal colic - Fever, tachycardia - Hypotension - Bronchospasm - Angioedema 1. Stop ASV infusion immediately 2. Administer epinephrine (adrenaline) IM or SC 3. Give antihistamines and corticosteroids 4. Treat shock if present 5. Resume ASV at a slower rate after symptoms subside Pyrogenic Reaction 1-2 hours after treatment - Fever - Rigors - Hypotension - Symptomatic treatment - Antipyretics - IV fluids if needed Late (Serum Sickness) Reaction 5-24 days (mean 7 days) after ASV - Fever - Itching - Urticaria - Arthralgia - Lymphadenopathy - Proteinuria - Antihistamines - Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) for 5-7 days Discontinue ASV infusion permanently (Option A) is incorrect because ASV is crucial for treating severe envenomation. After managing the reaction, ASV should be restarted. Continuing ASV infusion and administering corticosteroids (Option B) is incorrect because continuing the infusion during an anaphylactic reaction can worsen the patient's condition. The infusion should be stopped first. Administer heparin (Option D) is incorrect and potentially dangerous. Heparin is contraindicated in snake bite-induced coagulopathy and would not address the anaphylactic reaction. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4925324/#:~:text=Myotoxicity%3A%20Sea%20snake%20venom%20 contains,8%20hours%20after%20the%20bite.

questions.question: A 28-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being bitten by a snake on his right leg. He presents with severe pain and swelling at the bite site, and examination reveals two puncture wounds. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and he has gingival bleeding. The 20-minute whole blood clotting time test shows that the blood is incoagulable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.C: Apply a tight tourniquet above the bite site

questions.explanation: Hypotension (BP 90/60 mmHg) Gingival bleeding Incoagulable blood on the 20-minute whole blood clotting time test These symptoms strongly suggest a viper bite with significant systemic effects. According to the management guide, for severe poisoning with rapidly progressive or overt haemolysis or coagulopathy, the recommended antivenom dose is 150-200 ml. Management of Snakebite Management Details Indications/Notes First Aid -Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry) -Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No) - Reassure patient - Immobilize bitten limb - Transport to the hospital quickly - Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time Evaluation - Check for signs of envenomation - Monitor vital signs - Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time - Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae Antivenom Therapy - Mild: 50 ml - Moderate: 50-100 ml - Severe: 150-200 ml Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper. Indications: - Haemostatic abnormalities - Neurotoxicity - Cardiovascular dysfunction - Impaired consciousness - Rhabdomyolysis - Extensive local swelling Antivenom Administration - Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose - Infuse over 1-2 hours - Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours Supportive Care - Tetanus prophylaxis - Antibiotics (if severe local reaction) - Manage respiratory paralysis - Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4925324/#:~:text=Myotoxicity%3A%20Sea%20snake%20venom%20 contains,8%20hours%20after%20the%20bite. snakehelpline.com/snake-bite/first-aid/

questions.question: A 32-year-old farmer is brought to the emergency department after being bitten by a snake while working in his field in rural India. He presents with severe local pain, swelling, and gum bleeding. Within 2 hours, he develops diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive weakness in his limbs. Laboratory tests show prolonged prothrombin time and decreased fibrinogen levels. Which of the following snakes is most likely responsible for this envenomation?
questions.explanation: effects: Hemotoxic: Severe local pain and swelling, gum bleeding, prolonged prothrombin time, and decreased fibrinogen levels. Neurotoxic: Diplopia, dysphagia, and progressive limb weakness. This combination of hemotoxic and neurotoxic effects is characteristic of Russell's viper envenomation . Clinical features of various snake bites Feature Cobra (Option A) Krait (Option D) Russell's Viper Saw-scaled Viper (Option C) Image Venom Type Neurotoxic Neurotoxic Hemotoxic and Neurotoxic Hemotoxic Local Symptoms Mild to moderate pain and swelling Minimal local symptoms Severe pain, swelling, and tender lymphadenopathy Severe pain and swelling Neurological Symptoms - Ptosis - Paralysis of jaw/tongue - Pooling of secretions - Paradoxical respiration - Ptosis - Paralysis of jaw/tongue - Pooling of secretions - Paradoxical respiration - Diplopia - Dysphagia - Dysarthria/ dysphonia - Descending paralysis Generally not present Bleeding Manifestations Rare Rare - Gum bleeding - Epistaxis - Hematuria - Retro-peritoneal bleeding - Gum bleeding - Epistaxis - Hematuria - Can persist for weeks Renal Complications Rare Rare - Acute tubular necrosis - Renal failure Possible, but less common Coagulation Profile Usually normal Usually normal - Prolonged PT/INR - Decreased fibrinogen - Thrombocytopenia - Prolonged PT/INR - Decreased fibrinogen - Thrombocytopenia 20 WBCT Test Normal (solid clot) Normal (solid clot) Abnormal (rapid clot degradation) Abnormal (rapid clot degradation) Onset of Symptoms Rapid onset of neurological symptoms Often delayed onset, may occur during sleep Rapid onset of local and systemic symptoms Rapid onset of local symptoms

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with sepsis secondary to a urinary tract infection. After 48 hours, she develops acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. Her chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, and her PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 180 mmHg on PEEP of 8 cm H2O. An echocardiogram shows normal cardiac function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.C: Begin low tidal volume ventilation with 6 mL/kg predicted body weight

questions.explanation: (sepsis) Chest imaging: Bilateral infiltrates Origin of edema: Not due to cardiac failure (confirmed by echocardiogram) Oxygenation: PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 180 mmHg (indicating moderate ARDS: 100 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg) For moderate ARDS, the next best management option is low tidal volume ventilation with a predicted body weight of 6 mL/kg. ARDS: Diagnosis and Management Diagnosis (Berlin Definition) Timing Within 1 week of known clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms Chest Imaging Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, collapse, or nodules Origin of Edema Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload Oxygenation Mild (Grade A): 200 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥ 5 cm H2O) Moderate (Grade B): 100 mmHg < PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg Severe (Grade C & D): PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 100 mmHg Management Recommendations Grade A (Mild) Low tidal volume ventilation (4–8 ml/kg predicted body weight) and lower inspiratory pressures (plateau pressure < 30 cm H2O) Grade B (Moderate) Minimized plateau and driving pressures High PEEP (35–50 cmH2O for 20–40 s) Prone positioning Recruitment maneuvers ECMO in selected patients Grade C (Severe) Neuromuscular blockade in early ARDS Conservative fluid management Inhaled vasodilators as rescue therapy Avoid routine use of pulmonary artery catheter Grade D (Severe) Avoid high-frequency oscillatory ventilation Avoid β 2-agonists for improving outcomes High-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option A): Not recommended for routine use in ARDS. May be harmful in some patients. Inhaled nitric oxide (Option B): It is a Grade C recommendation- considered as rescue therapy in patients with severe hypoxemia. It may temporarily improve oxygenation. High-dose corticosteroids (Option D): Not specifically recommended in early ARDS Reference: 1. Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2227, 2228, 2229 2. pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7997862/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with severe pneumonia. He develops worsening respiratory symptoms and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray within 5 days. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism occurring in the alveoli during the early phase of this patient's condition?

options.B: Thickening of the alveolar basement membrane

questions.explanation: (exudative) phase of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). This occurs due to increased capillary permeability resulting from injury to the alveolar-capillary membrane. ARDS: Causes and Pathophysiology Category Details Direct Lung Injury Causes Pneumonia Aspiration of gastric contents Pulmonary contusion Near-drowning Toxic inhalation injury Indirect Lung Injury Causes Sepsis Severe trauma Multiple bone fractures Pancreatitis Burns Multiple transfusions Drug overdose Cardiopulmonary bypass Pathophysiology Exudative Phase (0-7 days): - Injury to alveolar capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes - Increased capillary permeability - Accumulation of protein-rich edema fluid in alveoli and interstitium - Formation of hyaline membranes - Neutrophil infiltration and activation - Release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF- α , IL-1, IL-8) - Impaired gas exchange and reduced lung compliance Proliferative Phase (7-21 days): - Proliferation of type II pneumocytes - Resolution of alveolar edema - Early fibroproliferation Fibrotic Phase (>21 days): - Collagen deposition and fibrosis in some patients Respiratory Distress Syndrome" data-author=""Swati Haldar Snehal Jadhav Vandana Gulati David J Beale Acharya Balkrishna Anurag Varshney Enzo Palombo Avinash Karpe Rohan Mahendra Shah "" data-hash="8405" data-license="CC BY 4.0" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure /Figur-e-4-T-he-micr-obiome-imm-une-pr-oteins-cellular-inter-action-in-the-lungs-Cr_fig2_373601839" data-tags="April2025" height="502" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/EN1m96XJNqg4rEE8VAaZ1744275953.png" width="647" /> Increased surfactant production (Option A): ARDS leads to surfactant dysfunction, not increased production. Thickening of the alveolar basement membrane (Option B): While this may occur later in ARDS, it's not a primary mechanism in the early phase. Fibrosis of the alveolar walls (Option D): This is a feature of the late (fibrotic) phase of ARDS, not the early phase. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine Edition 21st Page 2225, 2226, 2227

questions.question: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Laboratory results show: WBC: 14,000/ µ L Serum lactate: 1.8 mmol/L Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9 mg/dL) Chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. The patient requires 5 L/min of oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 90%. According to the Sepsis-3 criteria, which of the following is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. The clinical criteria for sepsis include: Suspected infection An acute increase of ≥ 2 SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) points In this case: The patient has a suspected lung infection (fever and chest X-ray infiltrate). There is evidence of organ dysfunction: Respiratory: PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 400 (requires oxygen) Renal: Creatinine increase > 0.3 mg/dL from baseline This meets the Sepsis-3 criteria for sepsis. SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) Score: The SOFA score is a more comprehensive tool used to assess organ dysfunction in potentially septic patients. It evaluates six organ systems: Respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 ratio) Cardiovascular (Mean arterial pressure and vasopressor requirements) Hepatic (Bilirubin level) Coagulation (Platelet count) Renal (Creatinine level or urine output) Neurological (Glasgow Coma Scale) Each system is scored from 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating more severe dysfunction. A total SOFA score ranges from 0 to 24. In the context of sepsis diagnosis, an acute increase in the SOFA score of 2 or more points is considered indicative of organ dysfunction associated with sepsis. SIRS (Option A): While the patient meets SIRS criteria, this term is no longer used in the Sepsis-3 definition. A patient is considered to have SIRS if they meet two or more of the following criteria: Body temperature >38°C (100.4°F) or <36°C (96.8°F) Heart rate >90 beats per minute Respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute or PaCO2 <32 mmHg White blood cell count >12,000/mm³, <4,000/mm³, or >10% immature bands While SIRS criteria are no longer part of the formal sepsis definition, they remain useful for quickly identifying patients who may need further evaluation for infection or organ dysfunction. Severe sepsis (Option C): This term was used in older definitions but is no longer part of Sepsis-3. Septic shock (Option D): The patient does not meet the criteria for septic shock, which requires vasopressor therapy to maintain MAP ≥ 65 mmHg and serum lactate >2.0 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page.2241, 2242.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male trauma patient is undergoing a massive transfusion protocol (MTP) following a severe motor vehicle accident. Two hours into the MTP, he developed acute respiratory distress. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates. His blood pressure is within normal limits, and BNP (Brain Natriuretic Peptide) levels are not elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: blood pressure, and normal BNP levels occurring within 6 hours of transfusion. Differences between Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) and Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO): Feature TRALI (Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury) TACO (Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload) (Option A) Definition Acute non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema following blood transfusion. Acute pulmonary edema due to volume overload from blood transfusion. Onset Usually within 6 hours of transfusion. Can occur during or up to 12 hours post-transfusion. Pathophysiology Immune-mediated injury to pulmonary capillaries leads to fluid leakage into alveoli. Volume overload causes increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation. Symptoms Sudden onset of dyspnea, hypoxemia, fever, hypotension. Dyspnea, orthopnea, rapid weight gain, hypertension . Physical Findings Crackles, tachypnea, no signs of fluid overload (e.g., jugular venous distension). Crackles, tachypnea, signs of fluid overload (e.g., elevated JVP, peripheral edema). Chest X-ray Findings diffuse pulmonary infiltrates" data-author="Glick Y" data-hash="8403" data-license="NA" data-source="https://radiopaedia.org/cases/transfusion-related-acute-lung-injury-trali" data-tags="April2025" height="297" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/DUQdUbLnFfwyS2cHNBnG1744275407.png" width="238" /> Bilateral diffuse pulmonary infiltrates (non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema). Cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, pleural effusions (cardiogenic pulmonary edema). Blood Pressure Hypotensive or normal. Hypertensive. Laboratory Findings Neutrophilia, leukocytosis, and anti-HLA antibodies in donor blood (in some cases). Elevated BNP (brain natriuretic peptide), no specific markers for TACO. Treatment Supportive care (oxygen, mechanical ventilation if necessary), no diuretics. Diuretics (e.g., furosemide), oxygen, stopping or slowing the transfusion. Prevention Use of leukocyte-reduced or HLA-matched blood products. Slow transfusion rate, avoid excess volume, and monitor for fluid overload. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (Option C) can occur in trauma patients and has similar radiographic findings. However, ARDS typically develops over 24-48 hours, not as acutely as described in this case. The direct relationship to transfusion makes TRALI more likely in this case. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema (Option D) would present with elevated blood pressure and increased BNP levels due to heart failure. The normal blood pressure and BNP levels in this case make cardiogenic pulmonary edema unlikely. Additionally, the acute onset in relation to transfusion points more toward a transfusion-related complication rather than a primary cardiac issue. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine,21st Edition, Volume I, Page. 894, 895.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with severe postpartum hemorrhage. Her vitals are: BP- 70/40 mmHg, HR- 135/min, RR- 28/min, Blood loss- Approximately 2L, ABC score- 3 Massive Transfusion Protocol is initiated. After round 1 of transfusion (4 units PRBC + 2 units FFP), the patient continues to bleed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.B: Give 4 units PRBC, 4 units FFP, and 1 unit SDP in Round 2
options.C: Only give additional PRBC to correct anemia
options.D: Start cryoprecipitate without checking fibrinogen levels

questions.explanation: unit SDP. Massive Transfusion Protocol Indications: ABC score >2 Major vessel trauma Severe hemorrhage (PPH, hematemesis) Penetrating trauma Hypotension Protocol Rounds: Round 1: Tranexamic acid 1g IV stat( CRASH-2 Trial : Administering tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of injury significantly reduces mortality from bleeding in trauma patients, while starting treatment after 3 hours may increase the risk of death.) 4 units PRBC (O-ve) 2 units FFP (AB+) Round 2: 4 units PRBC 4 units FFP 1 unit SDP Calcium gluconate Check coagulopathy Monitor fibrinogen Special Considerations: Factor VIIa: Only after temperature and pH stabilization Cryoprecipitate: If fibrinogen <100 mg/L (Option A) Factor VIIa is reserved for cases where bleeding continues despite achieving a temperature of 37°C and pH of 7.35. (Option C) Single-component therapy is inadequate in massive hemorrhage. (Option D) Cryoprecipitate is indicated only if fibrinogen <100 mg/L. Reference: www.aabb.org/education-and-resources/publications/technical-manual www.hematology.org/education/clinicians/guidelines-and-quality-care/clinical-practice-guidelines www.sccm.org/clinical-resources/guidelines www.who.int/publications/i/item/clinical-transfusion-practice-guidelines-for-medical-interns trialsjournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s13063-016-1750-1
